title: ability to remove routes?
body:
Not sure if this has been rejected before or if there's a way I don't see (or if it's actually a connect issue), but I really think it would be useful for dynamic applications to be able to remove routes. Currently if you want dynamic routes you need to handle that in a catch-all function possibly with a lot of sub-apps, which sort of defies the purpose of using express/connect in the first place.

```
app.VERB('/dynamic', ...)
app.unVERB('/dynamic')
```

title: Method for jsonp requests
body: The method for a post ajax call with ?callback=sth is considered GET, I don't know if this should be the case or not.

title: Get POST body with connect 3.0
body:
Are there any built-in methods to get the post params without using the bodyParser() and without using multipart?  I've updated to use:

```
app.use(express.json());
app.use(express.urlencoded());
```

So `req.body` is no longer available.  I'm using busboy to handle multipart file uploads, but need to still be able to just get post params.

Any help would be great!

Thank you

title: Flush view cache
body:
Hey,

at the moment there is no possibility to flush the view cache. It is enabled on production by default and at the moment I need to disable the cache on one of my views because the view changes from time to time. 

Is it possible to provide some method or an additional method to flush the cache? (I can write a pull request for that.) Or is it not planned to have these kind of function?

Regards,
Sascha

title: handle malformed paths better
body:
PR for weird cases described in #1352.

I preserved try..catch in place for performance reasons since node.js core seem to be doing [the same thing](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/querystring.js#L192), see [discussion](https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/2248).

title: Remove app inheritance, encourage using multiple routers instead of mounting apps
body:
See: #1637 
- Creating a new router should be easier by just doing `var router = express.router()`
- Need a `router.use()` method to make things closer to a real app or just have people do `.all()` (more of a doc issue)
- Needs updated examples and docs
- Remove all documentation about app inheritance

title: Migrate from Make to Grunt
body:
I'm primarily a Windows developer due to work. I'm interested in moving Express from Make to Grunt.js to improve the cross-platform dev experience.

Before I start hacking on it I'm curious this would be a useful contribution to the project.

However express lists the connect version as 2.11.2, not sure how that is possible.  However with current version of express this bug fix is not included.

https://github.com/amitaibu/node-multiparty/commit/37c25c9317fa19ca7ba0b58d47b7a8f42142c189#commitcomment-4241353

when i check req.files and the req.body the body is empty.
But if i send the metadata as a body parameter is working. is a bug or i have a error?

title: Tests: Missing `.address` property in `app` failing tests
body:
```
var app = express();
```

If I remember correctly, `app` used to have a `address` property which returned an object with the address and port properties. It seems to have been removed now.

Now the `address` property is available only on the HTTP server object `server`.

```
var server = http.createServer(app).listen( ... );
```

Because of the missing `address` property in `app`, 75 tests cases are failing with `TypeError: Cannot read property 'port' of null`.

Is there a quick fix for this, or do we have to rewrite the test cases?

title: Express 4.0
body:
Backwards incompatible changes. Woo! 
- [x] Remove express(1) #1820 
- [x] Remove app.configure #936
- [x] Change req.params to an object #1835
- [x] Remove/fix res.location() relative paths #1804 
- [x] Remove res.locals(obj) #1833 #1908 
- [x] Make app[VERB] each its own middleware #1909
- [x] Remove dependency on connect
- [x] Fix this error in node 0.11:
- [ ] ~~Remove app inheritance/revisit mounting `app` and what this means. Right now it is too confusing and not documented. #1843~~
- [ ] ~~Lazy cookies #1139~~
- [ ] ~~View middleware/module (allows for view engine as middleware)~~

title: Fix missing -d param for running tests
Grammar and punctuation fixes [ci skip]
change req.params to an object instead of an array
body: this seems to trip people up a lot even though it behaves the same an object. technically a breaking change, though the impact would probably be extremely minimal - it might be best to wait until a 4.0 or we'll get lots of flack from trolls

title: Template names with aliases for paths
body:
I think it would be nice feature if express could handle template names with aliases for paths.

For example 

```
var aliases =  { 
    alias1: __dirname + '/templates/main/'
    alias2: __dirname + '/templates/login/partials''
  };
app.set('aliases', aliases);
...
res.render('alias1::index', {}); // will resolve to __dirname + '/templates/main/index'
res.render('alias2::index', {}); // will resolve to __dirname + '/templates/login/partials/index'
```

Note that :: is separator. It can be changed to something else with app.set('alias separator'). 
Substring before :: is alias name and substring after is normal template name

title: res.locals not made available to hjs template
body:
I can't see any of my `res.locals` from hjs templates. I first noticed this while trying to use connect-cachify, which I gave up on, thinking it was broken. I've since realised that the problem is actually in express: 

Debugging `res.locals()` immediately prior to calling `res.render` shows that my locals are set as expected. I can force the values into my template by merging them explicitly with `options`, but this is annoying. I forked and debugged in express application.js and response.js and I believe I have found the problem - line 789 of response.js:

```
options._locals = self.locals;
```

`self.locals` is a function, so this doesn't actually expose the values to the template. I changed the line to read:

```
options._locals = self.locals();
```

...and now my templates see the values correctly and everything in my app works. 

However, I ran the express tests and they fail in res.render.js because they set up the text fixture with `locals` as an object, not a function, which makes me doubt my fix (I am very new to node and express). Am I on the right track, or way off?

title: buffer error on json parsing
body:
The last version of express (3.4.4) give me an error when I'm trying to parse a POST request. The error occured on body parsing ans more precisely in raw-body module (Buffer has no concat method).
The request was creating by the "request" module and I'm using the express json middleware as a parser.

Hope it helps

body: Fixes #1826. Removed the unused map and corrected the doc comment. No tests because who cares about correctness anyway?

title: csrf documentation says to use req.session._csrf, running express says to use req.csrfToken()
body:
the csrf documentation still has the old description for csrf, running an express instance will warn `req.session._csrf is deprecated, use req.csrfToken([callback]) instead`

probably requires a docupdate. Also note that the connect source for csrfToken does not take a callback, the siganture is simply `req.csrfToken()`

title: express shows wrong req.url when coming from proxy
body:
Express is showing wrong req.url when the request is coming from a client that has proxy turned on.

Example:

The client has a proxy setting: server.com:4000 and makes a request example.com/request

express server.com:4000 than shows req.url: http://www.example.comhttp://www.example.comhttp://www.example.com/request

But if you do a request directly against server without any proxy setting: server.com:4000/request req.url shows correct: /request

why is this?

title: res.redirect('toString') fails with 500
make express.logger log to a new date-suffixed file every day
body: For long running processes, using the logger will result in very large log files that cannot be parsed selectively. It would be very useful if the logger function could take arguments that allowed you to specify a log file location ending in ".log" and then indicate you want a new file made when the date changes.

title: HTTP parameter pollution in Express can aid attackers in bypassing security filters.
body:
If this is the first time you're hearing this term, HTTP Parameter Pollution aka HPP, then you need to read the links given below, to get an idea on what HPP can really do to a web application. 
##### TL;DR:

If you give a query as ?name=123&name=abc
Then express returns 123,abc 
##### Here are the links
- http://tacticalwebappsec.blogspot.in/2009/05/http-parameter-pollution.html
- https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_HTTP_Parameter_pollution_(OWASP-DV-004)

With that being said, lets look at how popular web applications treat the same problem.

![params](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/803950/1603762/bb3437fa-53af-11e3-84b6-140faa0d5f72.PNG)

Apparently, only ASP and a few others spit back all the occurrences of the the same parameter name value.

Provided, express is the de-facto nodejs web app framework, I think its about time we take this seriously and make sure that only one of the parameter name is harnessed. Either the first or the last occurrence would do.

title: Set response headers while redirecting a request
Removed Buffer call with 'binary' encoding option in auth example.
body:
According to the Node.js documentation for Buffer objects regarding the
'binary' encoding option:

"This encoding method is deprecated and should be avoided in favor of
Buffer objects where possible. This encoding will be removed in future
versions of Node."

Simply calling toString() with a 'base64' argument on the hash seems to
accomplish the same thing; this makes the code compatible with current
documentation as well as being a bit easier to follow.

The application will add style.scss in public/stylesheets/
and it will be compiled automatically by using "node-compass" module.

title: Accept URL as route param
body:
Hi,
I want to accept URL as router param:

``` javascript
app.get(/^\/url\/(.+)$/, function(req,res) {
    console.log(req.params);
});
```

But when I try: `curl http://localhost:1234/url/http://www.example.com`, I get this in the console:

```
[ 'http://www.example.com' ]
```

... it's OK. But when I try this: `curl http://localhost:1234/url/http://www.example.com/something`, I get this:

```
['http://www.example.com/url/http://www.example.com/url/http://www.example.com/url/http://www.example.com/url/http://www.example.com/something' ]
```

... it is really wrong. This crazy stuff happens only when the param URL starts with _http://_ and contains a least one more slash.

You can argue that I should escape param URL and you are right that works fine: `curl http://localhost:1234/url/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.example.com%2Fsomething`

... but this is not user friendly and I've seen applications using this pattern (not using Express) and e.g. Restify (http://mcavage.me/node-restify) handle this correctly.

title: Expose `compile` function of logger middleware
body:
It'd be useful to be able to use the `compile` function used in `lib/middleware/logger.js`.

My use case right now is that I want to use the `default` format unless the request header `X-Forwarded-For` is present, in which case I want to use exactly the `default` format but with the remote IP switched out for whatever `X-Forwarded-For` is. So I want to do a regex replace on the default string, replacing one token with another, and have the `compile` function run on the result.

That'd save me reinventing the wheel.

Or is there a simpler way to do what I'm looking for?

title: "Weird" utf-8 characters in POST body causing content-length mismatch
body:
When I submit a POST request and the body contains characters like "å", the server responds with a 400 because the content-length didn't match. I'm guessing that the problem is that multiple byte utf-8 characters are being assumed to be only one byte long when they are counted.

I'm not sure if this is a bug in express or connect or raw-body. Hopefully you can pass it along if it's not an express bug. This bug only seems to have appeared in express versions 3.4.2 and later.

Here's the error message: 

```
{ [Error: request size did not match content length] status: 400, received: 545, expected: 546 } 'Error: request size did not match content length\n    at IncomingMessage.onEnd (/home/user/my-project/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/node_modules/raw-body/index.js:52:17)\n    at IncomingMessage.g (events.js:175:14)\n    at IncomingMessage.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:92:17)\n    at _stream_readable.js:910:16\n    at process._tickCallback (node.js:415:13)'
```

title: app.use(express.limit()) not working
body:
I have written a StackOverflow reply which describes the problem in detail. It can be found here : http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19917401/node-js-express-request-entity-too-large

Is this a problem related to my implementation or really a framework bug? It seems it does not work for anyone, from what I saw while searching earlier about the problem...

title: streaming view rendering
body:
Allows for a view engine to return a stream upon being asked to render a
path. This allows for the engine to simply stream out data as it is
loaded from disk (or other IO location) without having to collect it all
first and then send it.

Fallback mode for all existing engines that call `fn` upon completion
takes over if no stream is returned. This works for both app.render and
res.render

title: Streaming views?
add :date output for logger dev format
body:
Hi guys! One pain when using express is that its `dev` log doesn't print the `date` of requests. When you trace back the log file to find/debug something, it is really hard to analyze and estimate the problem without dates. Can you imagine a log without time dimension? It would lose much of its power.

Of course I can custom the logger format with everything I want, while with some efforts of google and reading into codes of express and connect. I know express just exposes the logger property of connect, but that is not an excuse. Logging request with time is everyone wants and it should be default.

If you agree with me, I can contribute on this.

title: Parameters handling
HTTP spec says Location header should have absolute URI
body:
The HTTP 1.1 spec at http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.30 says the Location header's value is supposed to be an absolute URI. I could be wrong but I believe this means it should always have the scheme and domain, never just the path.

When I use `res.location('/page2')` I'm getting exactly that back in the location value, but I wonder if Express should send out the full URL?

Obviously most (all?) browsers don't mind either way, but I wanted to flag it, since it seems a good idea to follow the spec as closely as possible.

Do you have any idea? 

Thank you

title: res.send sends empty array when passed any sparse array
body:
Let's say I create a sample application using the express boilerplate and add the following: 

```
var indArr=[1,2,3];
var sparseArr=[]; sparseArr["a"]=1,sparseArr["b"]=2,sparseArr["c"]=3;
app.get('/indArr',function(req,res){res.send(indArr)});
app.get('/sparseArr',function(req,res){res.send(sparseArr)});
```

Navigating to the page, /indArr works as expected:

```
[
  1,
  2,
  3
]
```

However, /sparseArr drops everything (probably because sparseArr.length=0)

```
[]
```

(Sparse arrays themselves aren't valid JSON, so I would expect it to be transformed into an object (i.e. {"a":1, "b":2, "c",3}) and sent.)

If there's a specific reason it's done this way, let me know, but it seems a bit counter-intuitive to me.

title: add view basedir options
body:
view basedir now is only controlled by app.set('views', path)
but sometime basedir may be variable like theme or other
maybe we can change ./lib/application line:491

``` javascript
   view = new (this.get('view'))(name, {
      defaultEngine: this.get('view engine'),
      root: this.get('views'),
      engines: engines
   });
```

`root: this.get('views')`  ==> `root: opts.views || this.get('views')`

and views dir can be controlled by res.locals

title: valum file uploader resets session in expressjs
body:
I am trying to upload an file using valum's ajax upload. On the server side I am using expressjs and it is a post verb. on the server side it sends back the req.session.id as json(sends the current sessionid). But at the end of the upload request the session cookie is changed(the session is reset on the server/all the save variables are gone). I am not sure what is happening. And this is happening with APPFOG not on the localhost.

I am on express 3.2.6

```
app.post '/photo/upload', (req,res)->
    res.json {id: req.session.id}

```

front end

```
            uploader = new qq.FileUploader
                            element: document.getElementById('file-uploader')
                            action: '/photo/upload'
                            allowedExtensions: [ "jpg", "jpeg", "png", "gif" ]
                            sizeLimit: 0
                            minSizeLimit: 0
                            onSubmit: (id, filename) ->  
                            onComplete: (id, filename, responseJSON) ->
                                photoId = responseJSON.id

```

title: incorrect relative paths with res.location
body:
per https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/1802#discussion_r7386223, `res.location('./relative')` currently sends an incorrect URL. 
- `/posts` -> `./new` should resolve to `/new`, not `/posts/new`
- `/posts/` -> `./new` should resolve to `/posts/new` (which it does correctly)

but this would break backwards compatibility, so i would change this in 4.x unless people care.

EDIT: meh, we'll probably just remove this in the future. browsers handle them correctly, anyways

title: DELETE request without an method
body:
I was testing with Postman an I encountered this weird error:

File: https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/router/index.js#L223

> TypeError: Cannot call method 'toLowerCase' of null
>     at Router.matchRequest (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:223:27)
>     at pass (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:104:30)
>     at Router._dispatch (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:173:5)
>     at Object.router (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:33:10)
>     at next (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:190:15)
>     at Object.handle (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/lib/express/index.js:168:4)
>     at Context.next (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/sails/node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/proto.js:190:15)
>     at Context.actions.pass (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/passport/lib/passport/context/http/actions.js:77:8)
>     at /Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/passport/lib/passport/strategies/session.js:61:12
>     at pass (/Users/thomas/Dropbox/www/WebBlueprint/Api/node_modules/passport/lib/passport/index.js:315:31)

I'm using sailsjs with passportjs. I tested it on Node v0.11.8 on OS X 10.8.5 and it gave this erorr. Then I tried it on Node v0.10.21 and it didn't gave this error.

So for some reason in v0.11 when making a DELETE request, the method doesn't get added to the `req` object

Unpublish 3.4.3, publish as 3.5.0

title: connect will deprecate some methods in connect 3.0
body:
I get this warning from my app.

```
connect.multipart() will be removed in connect 3.0
visit https://github.com/senchalabs/connect/wiki/Connect-3.0 for alternative
connect.limit() will be removed in connect 3.0
```

I use `express.bodyParser()` so I guess `connect.bodyParser()` is involved? Then the solution seems to be:

```
app.use(connect.urlencoded())
app.use(connect.json())
```

Since I'm not using `connect` directly I guess the fix needs to be done inside `express`?

title: Reference to non-existent function "confirm" from commander.js
body:
Express 3.4.1 upgrades the dependency version of commander to 2.0.0. This version of commander no longer supports the confirm() method and yet it is referenced in the "directory not empty" check. This produces:

``` private/tmp/bug/node_modules/express/bin/express:251
      program.confirm('destination is not empty, continue? ', function(ok){
              ^
TypeError: Object #<Command> has no method 'confirm'
    at /private/tmp/bug/node_modules/express/bin/express:251:15
    at /private/tmp/bug/node_modules/express/bin/express:382:5
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
```

title: when i init express in an non-empty directory
body:
```
express .

/usr/local/share/npm/lib/node_modules/express/bin/express:251
      program.confirm('destination is not empty, continue? ', function(ok){
              ^
TypeError: Object #<Command> has no method 'confirm'
    at /usr/local/share/npm/lib/node_modules/express/bin/express:251:15
    at /usr/local/share/npm/lib/node_modules/express/bin/express:382:5
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
```

the error info appears.

and i did some simple research, found out it was beacuse `commander.js` remove those commands like `confirm` etc in this [commit](https://github.com/visionmedia/commander.js/commit/bf5e1f5ec9fb1af23dd873117558575cd01d7415)

so, what now?

title: req.user & req.remoteUser not correctly set if async method used
Can't upload files using 3.3.4 and above
Etag Support Only When Content-Length > 1024?
body:
Hi,

I was wondering why the etag generation is offered only under the condition len > 1024:
https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/response.js#L136

Don't you think that this should be configurable or something?

On my case, I'm building an URL for ajax-pooling and it has a json-hal object as response-body and it has with only 2 or 3 fields (except related _links). The problem is the content-length on that action in question is less then 1024 and the ETag isn't generated.

And I also couldn't find any unit test covering this specific condition len > 1024 on the source-code so I imagine that it's not THAT significant, right?

question regarding 404 response in connect proto
use is ignored when used after get
Add Runnable.com button
body: Runnable button, as single commit

title: express.static() is undocumented
body: The Expressjs API reference at http://expressjs.com/api.html mentions static() middleware in several places, but does not actually have an entry for it. One use of it is shown under directory() entry, but there is no documentation on e.g. the options accepted.

title: Express command generate files with CR replaced by Commas?
body:
System: Windows 8.1 (I tried this on other Windows 8.1 and worked fine)

I'm having a weird behavior when using the express command to generate a default web site.All files that are generated have their /r/n replaced by a comma.
As an example the default app.js looks like:
,/**, \* Module dependencies., */,,var express = require('express');,var routes = require('./routes');,var user = require('./routes/user');......

All files no matter of their type gets badly generated.
I tried to repeat that on a different laptop with windows 8.1 and kind of the same install. There the express commands generate proper files. I got this error only on my laptop.

Any idea where I could look to resolve this?

Any help will be much appreciated.

Alex.

title: jsonp callback error
In nested apps, subApp's middleware is run by the main app
body:
In this example ([gist](https://gist.github.com/d4goxn/6941157)), where an app uses a sub app, the sub app's middleware executes for all of the routes in every app. Also, it is executed twice for the sub app's routes.

If I add a path prefix to the sub app's middleware, then the middleware works the way I need it too. I am wondering if this is how nested apps are supposed to work, or if I have found a bug?

title: calling next() twice
Rules for post issues
body:
I was looking at the issues, and I realized that there are many unanswered. But it's because they lack information or is very old versions. So I propose a set of rules for all to fulfill :) So can develop better Express and can answer questions.

I know it sounds a bit presumptuous of me, but is the best way.

title: impossible to get 404 when using res.format() middleware
can't find this in the docs: capturing the entire "tail" using an app.param
body:
I can't find any mention in the documentation on how to do this, or whether it cannot be done:  is there a way to make a param capture "everything beyond this point", so that `app.get('/:tail', function...)` on a domain like `http://example.org/thing/with/arbitrary/nesting` puts `thing/with/arbitary/nesting` into the `tail` parameter?

The use case is mox-server, which can host data stored to disk by a noxmox AWS S3 emulator. Files are sent to the noxmox library as if it's S3, so their "put" instruction is on an arbitrarily deep URL, but noxmox will store the blob on disk as just `bucketname/fileWithSlashesEscaped`, so in order to resolve URL requests, mox-server needs to grab a tail for a URL so that it can do the uri-encode step on the string with slashes and then fetch the file from disk based on that.

title: Avoid express overwriting you package.json file if it already exists
body:
If you start a new project by running `npm init` and then thinks you want a express boilerplate and writes `express` and init in the current directory, your new package.json will be overwritten by express, because it does not look for the file first.

I thought about making a function similar to write(), so it would be exists(), but the exists command is already so short, and then you would have to pass the write command as a callback, that would make it more messy.

Was i right?

title: Middleware to generate REST API documentation?

Anyone know about an existing express middleware (or side lib) which can generate some basic documentation based on the routes configuration?

title: app.delete() raising syntax errors
body:
'delete' being a reserved keyword in Javascript, app.delete() is raising syntax errors in IDE like Nodeclipse and the like.

'delete' is the antonym keyword for 'new': nobody would ever use any construct like app.new() in express - just to point out how deep this mistake is to me.

A much better syntax would be app.remove() as 'remove' is not a reserved keyword - what a language reserved keywords are about if they are just ignored so lightly?

Is it still possible to address such an issue or is this 'delete' construct a legacy forever?
